verses.text: Then Elihu answered and said:
verses.comment: Elihu continues his speeches in response to Job and his friends, claiming to speak with wisdom. Elihu's role here sets the stage for God's final response, emphasizing the importance of listening to divinely inspired counsel.

verses.text: "Hear my words, you wise men; listen to me, you who have knowledge.
verses.comment: Elihu appeals to the wisdom of his audience, suggesting that true counsel requires careful listening and real understanding, a motif echoed throughout wisdom literature (Proverbs 1:5).

verses.text: For the ear tests words as the palate tastes food.
verses.comment: Elihu echoes Job’s earlier statement (Job 12:11), stressing discernment in judging what is heard—just as one discerns good food.

verses.text: Let us choose for ourselves what is right; let us know among ourselves what is good.
verses.comment: Elihu invites collective discernment of truth and righteousness, an early form of communal deliberation, prefiguring later church councils on matters of doctrine.

verses.text: For Job has said, 'I am in the right, and God has taken away my justice;
verses.comment: Elihu summarizes Job’s complaint: He claims innocence, yet feels God has unjustly afflicted him.

verses.text: Should I lie against my right? My wound is incurable, though I am without transgression.'
verses.comment: Job maintains his innocence and the unjust nature of his suffering, anticipating the biblical theme of the righteous sufferer, which is fulfilled in Christ (Isaiah 53:4-6).

verses.text: What man is like Job, who drinks up scoffing like water?
verses.comment: Elihu criticizes Job for embracing mockery, using imagery found elsewhere in Job to describe those immersed in wrongdoing.

verses.text: He goes in company with those who do evil and walks with wicked men.
verses.comment: By suggesting Job aligns with the wicked, Elihu is highlighting the danger of assuming God’s justice can be questioned—a recurring biblical warning.

verses.text: For he has said, 'It profits a man nothing that he should delight in God.'
verses.comment: Elihu distorts Job’s argument to rebuke him, setting up a correction of the idea that devotion to God is futile. This foreshadows New Testament themes of reward for faithfulness (Hebrews 11:6).

verses.text: Therefore, hear me, you men of understanding: far be it from God to do wickedness, and from the Almighty to act unjustly.
verses.comment: God's absolute justice is affirmed, a central doctrine of biblical theology, carried through both Testaments.

verses.text: For according to a man's deeds He repays him, according to his ways, He brings it upon him.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the biblical principle of retributive justice, which undergirds much of the wisdom literature (Proverbs 24:12).

verses.text: Truly, God will not do evil, and the Almighty will not pervert justice.
verses.comment: A restatement of God’s perfect justice—this theme finds its fulfillment in Christ, who is both just and justifier (Romans 3:26).

verses.text: Who appointed Him over the earth? Who put Him in charge of the whole world?
verses.comment: Elihu rhetorically asks about God’s sovereignty—God's authority comes from Himself, not from man.

verses.text: If He were to set His heart on man and gather to Himself His spirit and His breath,
verses.comment: Life depends entirely on God’s will; echoes the creation account where God breathes life into man.

verses.text: all flesh would perish together, and mankind would return to dust.
verses.comment: A reminder of human mortality, connecting to the doctrine of creation and the dependence of all life on God.

verses.text: "If you have understanding, hear this; listen to what I say.
verses.comment: Elihu calls for humility and teachability—a posture encouraged throughout the wisdom books.

verses.text: Can one who hates justice govern? Will you condemn the righteous and mighty One?
verses.comment: God is both sovereign and perfectly just—a central tenet for the faithful.

verses.text: Is it right to say to a king, 'You are worthless,' or to nobles, 'You are wicked'?
verses.comment: Showing respect for authority is an enduring biblical principle (see also Romans 13:1-7). Authority reflects heavenly realities.

verses.text: Yet He shows no partiality to princes, nor regards the rich above the poor, for they all are the work of His hands.
verses.comment: God’s impartiality is rooted in His justice; all people are equal before Him—a truth shown in His dealings with Israel and fulfilled in Christ’s ministry (James 2:1-7).

verses.text: In a moment they die; at midnight the people are shaken and pass away; the mighty are taken away without a hand.
verses.comment: Death comes to all without warning; God’s sovereignty is displayed in life and in judgment.

verses.text: For His eyes are on the ways of a man, and He sees all his steps.
verses.comment: The omniscience of God is a great biblical theme—God sees everything, even what is hidden (Psalm 139:1-4).

verses.text: There is no darkness or shadow deep enough to hide evildoers from Him.
verses.comment: This verse echoes the theme that no one can hide from God's judgment and knowledge.

verses.text: For God does not have to examine a man further, that he should go before God in judgment.
verses.comment: God’s perfect knowledge negates any need for investigation—He knows the heart. This foreshadows final judgment teachings in the New Testament.

verses.text: He shatters the mighty without inquiry and sets up others in their place.
verses.comment: God raises up and brings down rulers as He wills—a doctrine evident in sacred history and fulfilled in Christ’s eternal kingship.

verses.text: Therefore He knows their deeds; He overthrows them in the night, and they are crushed.
verses.comment: God’s intimate knowledge of all people means His judgments are righteous and timely.

verses.text: He strikes them as wicked men in a public place,
verses.comment: God’s justice is both public and comprehensive, demonstrating to all His authority.

verses.text: because they turned aside from Him and considered none of His ways,
verses.comment: Those who forsake God’s law are subject to His chastisement, linking to covenant themes found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: so that they cause the cry of the poor to come before Him; and He hears the cry of the afflicted.
verses.comment: God’s concern for the poor and oppressed is a persistent theme, fulfilled in Jesus’ ministry (Luke 4:18).

verses.text: When He is quiet, who can condemn? When He hides His face, who can see Him? He rules over man and nation alike,
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty has no equal. His will cannot be thwarted, whether His actions are seen or hidden.

verses.text: so that godless men will not rule, nor will any ensnare the people.
verses.comment: God ordains righteous leaders for the good of His people—foreshadowing later teachings about church leadership and authority.

verses.text: "Suppose someone says to God, 'I have borne punishment; I will offend no more;
verses.comment: A model of repentance is presented—a key doctrine throughout Scripture, especially realized through the means of grace and reconciliation.

verses.text: teach me what I do not see; if I have done wrong, I will do so no more,'
verses.comment: This attitude of humility and willingness to be instructed echoes the biblical vision of continual moral growth.

verses.text: should God reward you on your terms, because you refuse to repent? You must choose, not I; therefore, speak what you know.
verses.comment: God is not subject to individual demands but to His own perfect will. Repentance and submission to God’s rule remain necessary for true relationship with Him.

verses.text: Men of understanding will say to me, wise men who hear me will say:
verses.comment: Elihu appeals again to collective wisdom, reflecting the necessity of consulting those formed in spiritual understanding.

verses.text: 'Job speaks without knowledge; his words lack insight.'
verses.comment: Elihu characterizes Job’s arguments as lacking wisdom, highlighting the need for divine revelation and tradition in the discernment of truth.

verses.text: Would that Job were tested to the utmost, because he answers like wicked men.
verses.comment: Elihu calls for further testing of Job, but God’s coming response shows suffering is not always a direct result of wickedness. This foreshadows the mystery of suffering and redemptive suffering in Christian theology.

verses.text: For he adds rebellion to his sin; he claps his hands among us and multiplies his words against God."
verses.comment: Elihu warns that Job’s persistent arguments border on rebellion. This sets up the narrative for God’s reply, emphasizing patience, submission, and trust in divine wisdom. The passage invites believers to humility before the mystery of God’s providence.
